entry.title: Integration Suite Event Mesh - Management API
entry.content:
Hi Gurus,

I have noticed that Integration Suite Event Mesh is now offering an API that was previously only available for Standalone Event Mesh: the EM Management API.

Standalone EM APIs

https://api.sap.com/package/SAPEventMeshDefaultPlan/rest

This API is leveraged by SAP CALM for health monitoring of the Integration Suite broker.

Unfortunately, SAP has kept the details to themselves, and the API Business Hub does not show the new API for Integration Suite.

Integration Suite Event Mesh API

https://api.sap.com/package/EventMeshinSAPIntegrationSuite/rest

In the API Business Hub, there are no details about the Management API being leveraged by SAP CALM, but we know it is there.

We have not been able to determine the BasePath for this API yet, as it has changed compared to the Standalone version (https://XXX:YYYY/hub/rest/api/v1/management/...).

Has anyone found the BasePath for this API?

Best regards,
Mikel

entry.title: Re: SAP S/4HANA Cloud ERP (public) - Nielsen ID for Busin...
entry.content:
Dear @KatjaWa,

In Public Cloud the Nielsen Indicator is a standard marketing attribute in Business Partner data BUT SAP currently does not provide an SSCUI in CBC to maintain the Nielsen ID catalog / value help which is why your F4 help is empty

More details from SAP Community:

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-q-a/about-customer-master-data/qaq-p/12370090

What you can do instead in Public Cloud (safe options / recommended workaround):

1.Use a custom field instead of the standard Nielsen field:

  • Create a custom field on Business Partner in Custom Fields app
  • Use field type Code List so you get your own maintained value help or Text if you don’t need validation

 

  • In your ECC to Public Cloud replication mapping, map ECC Nielsen value into that custom field

Summary: This is the cleanest approach in Public Cloud when SAP doesn’t expose configuration for a standard value list

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: From PI/PO to SAP Edge Integration Cell: Initial Sizing Approach and Planning for HA/Non-HA Setup
entry.content:
SAP Edge Integration Cell- Sizing Approach 

Planning the migration from SAP PI/PO to the SAP Integration Suite requires accurate infrastructure sizing for the Edge Integration Cell.

In this post, I demonstrate a practical sizing approach by applying the official Sizing Guide and SAP Note 3247839  (Prerequisites) to a real-world scenario.

By analyzing PI/PO Message Performance, this blog post helps you determine the necessary hardware resources to ensure a stable foundation for your migration to SAP Edge Integration Cell.  Furthermore, I will outline the key differences between High Availability (HA) and Non-HA setups, highlighting the critical factors you need to consider when selecting this two setups. 

 

   

1. Input for Sizing – Business Throughput

Business Throughput is the number of business transactions or messages an SAP system processes within a given time, usually specified as messages or transactions per hour or second. It is a key metric in sizing because it determines the necessary CPU, memory, and other resources to handle the expected workload effectively.

Sizing with Business Throughput involves converting hourly throughput to messages per second to account for load distribution and peak times. SAP uses benchmarks like SAPS (SAP Application Performance Standard) to translate business throughput into hardware requirements.

In summary: Business Throughput quantifies the expected transactional load and is the foundation for planning the infrastructure capacity to ensure optimal SAP system performance and stability.

 

In our case, we calculate the SAP PI/PO Business Throughput, which measures the volume of messages or transactions processed by the Process Integration and Process Orchestration system within a defined timeframe. This calculation is essential for sizing the infrastructure to support the expected load and ensure optimal system performance.

1.1. Scope

The following components of the EIC will be considered for sizing:

  • Worker: Executes integration flows within the Integration Suite runtime, built on Apache Camel. Responsible for both synchronous and asynchronous message processing.
  • Policy Engine: Envoy-based runtime with SAP-specific extensions, enforces policies such as traffic management and security for API proxies.
  • PostgreSQL Database: Relational database system for storing structured metadata and logging data generated during integration scenarios.
  • Redis: In-memory data store used primarily for caching and storing operational data, including support for API traffic management policies.
  • Message Service: Implements asynchronous integration patterns using the JMS protocol and manages local event processing.

 

2. Required input factors 

The following factor will be required:

  • Number of messages per second
  • Size of average payload
  • Complexity of Integration flow

 

Number of messages per second

When determining the number of messages per second for sizing purposes, it is important to clarify and standardize the assumptions:

  • The “number of messages per second” should refer to the maximum throughput during peak periods, not an average across the year.​
  • Identify the peak time range (for example, analyze which month has the highest message volume). Subsequently, break down the peak month to the number of messages per second and consider the average payload size for that period.
  • When calculating, consider the following questions:
    • Should weekends be included in the calculation, or is message traffic significantly lower?
    • Should sizing be based on 24-hour operation, or does your existing PI/PO system operate during defined business hours only (e.g., 8 hours per day)?

This approach ensures that capacity is planned according to realistic worst-case load, which is recommended to guarantee stable system performance even during short-lasting throughput peaks

3. Delivered Messages statistics- Performance Monitoring

Crucial Assumption- Peak Period:

For the analysis and sizing calculation, message statistics tables were directly extracted from SAP PI/PO Performance Monitoring. The available week of message data was chosen as the reference peak period. Because only one week of message statistics was available at the time of analysis, all sizing calculations are based on this week—used here as the reference "peak period."

Going this approach because possible higher peaks is not yet accessible.

By using this, the system is planned to handle at least the highest observed workload, safeguarding against typical peak scenarios.​

To make the evaluation as clear and practical as possible, the message data was systematically split into three tables:

  1. An All Messages Statistics Table capturing all messages from the week, combining both synchronous (real-time) and asynchronous (delayed/queued) communications.
  2. A Synchronous Messages Statistics Table including only real-time message exchanges, where instant system-to-system response is required.
  3. An Asynchronous Message Statistics Table gathering messages processed without immediate answers, reflecting queued or scheduled processes.

For each of these datasets and every reviewed time interval, two main metrics are calculated:

Average payload size: Indicates the typical data volume per message, usually in kilobytes or megabytes.

Average number of messages per second: Shows the sustained rate at which the system processes messages.

By distinguishing between message types and quantifying peak load figures, the resource requirements for both synchronous and asynchronous scenarios can be more accurately determined.The ultimate goal is to ensure that system capacity meets actual business needs even during the busiest periods.

3.1. All Messages Statistics Table including Sync and Async-Complex

 

a.All Messages Statistics Table -Average payload size

 

b.  All Messages Statistics Table - Message per second

 

3.2 Synchronous Statistics Messages Table

a. Synchronous Statistics Message Table - Average payload size

 

 

b. Synchronous Statistics Message Table - Message per second

 

3.3 Asynchronous Statistics Messages Table

 

a. Asynchronous Message Table - Average payload size

 

b. Asynchronous Message Table - Message per second

 

 

4. Sizing Approach for Worker (Complex Integration Flow)

For sizing the Worker component, all calculations are carried out using complex integration flows. Separating simple from complex flows in real-world systems is often very time-consuming and difficult because this distinction is usually not visible in the message logs.

 

Furthermore, experience and SAP guidelines show that the actual difference in sizing results between simple and complex flows is not significant. For simplicity and to avoid unnecessary complexity, we base all calculations on complex flows. This guarantees that the system is sufficiently dimensioned for any type of integration workload.

 

SAP Application Performance Standard (SAPS)

The actual sizing is performed using the SAP Application Performance Standard (SAPS).

For all worker-related calculations in this guide, the rule is applied that 1 CPU core equals roughly 1400 SAPS.

4.1. Synchronous - Complex Integration Flows

Input

  1. Average Payload size for Synchronous -Complex Integration Flow: 12,50KB
  2. Throughput = 0,0077 messages per seconds

Applying linear ratio for payload size

If your actual average payload size or message throughput differs from the values in the predefined table below—which lists CPU and memory requirements for specific throughput and payload sizes—you should use linear scaling to estimate the required resources.

Steps to apply linear scaling:

  1. Identify the closest payload size in the reference table that is nearest to your actual average payload size.
    • This closest size is called the reference payload size.

  2. Calculate the scaled message throughput using:

     

  3. Round the scaled message throughput number to the nearest whole number.

  4. Use the CPU, memory, and instance recommendations from the table for the reference payload size and this scaled message rate to size your system.

 

 

Determined results

12,5KB/100 * 0,0077= 0,00096 scaled messages per second

 

Correspond to the table below

// (reminder:1400 SAPS = 1CPU)

4.2.  Asynchronous- Complex Integration Flows( Variant 2)

 

Input

  1. Average Payload size for Asynchronous -Complex Integration Flow(Variant 2): 668,67KB
  2. Throughput = 0,56 messages per seconds


     

Determined results

5.      Message Service Tier for Asynchronous Messages

For Message Service Tier selection, message throughput usually isn't the deciding factor—the number of required JMS queues and general storage are far more critical. You should carefully review your scenarios to determine how many queues you need, consider the asynchronous interface communications and pipeline concepts for Integration Suite.

 

Once you've selected a tier, you should test and validate if your throughput matches your selected message service tier.

 

Input

  1. Average Payload size for asynchronous -Complex Integration Flow: 668,67KB
  2. Throughput = 0,56 messages per seconds

 

668,67KB/1024 * 0,56= 0,36 scaled messages per second for 1MB payload size

 

 

For production setups, it is recommended to consider Message Service Tier 250 or higher.

7.      Database Sizing (PostgreSQL)

7.1. Storage

Input

  • Total messages for 1 week: 345,295 messages
  • Retention period: 30 days. Therefore, the number of messages per month is calculated as 345,295 * 4 = 1,381,180 messages.
  • Approximate disk space: 13.81 GB, rounded up to 15 GB.

 

 

Determined results

 

This calculation assumes message logging at the INFO level. TRACE-level logging or additional datastore usage could increase storage needs by ~50%.

Additional factors like MPL attachments, trace data, general overhead, datastore entries, and message store entries also consume storage.

 

For reliability, size for at least 32 GB -->>ideally 64 GB—a low-cost safeguard.

9.      Sizing Output for EIC

Why do we start with the Non-HA Baseline? We start our calculation with the smallest standard configuration: the Non-High Availability (Non-HA) setup.

In our specific example, the existing PI/PO system has very low message traffic. Due to this low workload, we anticipate that the SAP Edge Integration Cell will not require extensive hardware resources.

At this step, we have not yet decided if the final SAP EIC will be an HA or Non-HA setup. Therefore, we use this minimum baseline as a starting point. Then, we add our specific calculated workload (the "Delta") to it.

Finally, after seeing the total requirements, we compare the results against the HA and Non-HA setups to make a final conclusion

9.4.      Summary and Conclusion 

The summary of the sizing results for SAP Edge Integration Cell is based on the final table of the document. The recommended sizing for the non-HA setup amounts to 13 CPU and 50.5 GiB of memory for all EIC components, with a mandatory storage requirement of at least 101 GB and optionally up to 71 GB more. For the external database/store components, PostgreSQL is specified with 1 CPU, 2 GB RAM, and 64 GB storage, and Redis with 1 CPU and 1 GB RAM. These total values are derived from summing the individual components and form the basis for technical infrastructure planning.

The calculation approach was based on real peak load data from one observed week, separating synchronous and asynchronous message types to assess their maximum resource requirements independently. By using these peak values, the sizing ensures the system capacity is designed to handle actual business throughput during the busiest periods, following SAP’s best-practice. The result shows that the calculated values are clearly above the minimum requirement for a non-HA system but do not reach the requirements for an HA setup (which would require at least 20 CPU, 64 GiB RAM, and 204 GiB storage)

Difference between HA and non-HA Setup 

The non-HA sizing results for SAP Edge Integration Cell show that with 13 CPUs, 50.5 GiB RAM, and at least 101 GB of storage, the setup exceeds the minimum required for non-HA, but it is still below the requirements for a high-availability (HA) setup, which needs 20 CPUs, 64 GiB RAM, and 204 GB of storage. External datastores and optional components are not included in these figures.

A non-HA setup typically operates around 40 pods on one or two worker nodes. An HA setup runs approximately 80 to 90 pods and is designed to provide higher availability and failover capabilities, especially for the Message Service, which is primarily used for asynchronous scenarios and JMS queues. In non-HA, the Message Service runs as a single instance; in HA, it operates with two replicas and an additional monitoring pod so that if one instance fails, the other can take over, significantly reducing interruptions in JMS-based processing.

The Message Service is a critical component, as it manages asynchronous messages and internal system events. In a non-HA environment, this service exists as a single instance; if it fails, all integration flows using JMS queues fail during the downtime, while other integration flows without JMS are not affected. During this period, deployments and undeployments of artifacts on the EIC also fail, and new Message Processing Logs (MPLs) are no longer written to the database.

Once the Message Service in a non-HA environment is available again, all previously persisted messages remain and will be reprocessed, as long as the underlying persistence volume has not been deleted or replaced. However, if the EIC – including the Message Service – is uninstalled and reinstalled, all queues and messages within them will be lost, since the components are rebuilt from scratch.

An HA deployment runs at least two replicas of the Message Service along with a monitoring pod. This setup enables immediate failover: if one replica fails, the second takes over with minimal interruption, allowing JMS-based integration flows to continue with little or no downtime. Upscale activities on the Message Service will always result in a brief downtime, but in an HA setup this disruption is much shorter than when operating with a single instance in non-HA mode.

Key Aspect for Message Service :

  • What happens to messages if the Message Service fails in a non-HA setup?

For the duration of the downtime the following things will happen: All Integration Flows that use JMS Queues will fail, other IFlows are not affected. All (un-)deployments of artefacts onto EIC fail. No MPLs will be written to the DB anymore.

 

  • Are messages in the queue lost, and can they be processed again when the Message Service is restarted?

Once the Message Service is up again/has restarted all previously stored messages are retained and will get processed again as long as the underlying Persistent Volume has not been wiped out. If EIC has been uninstalled and re-installed again, the Message Service also gets deleted completely --> all queues and messages are lost.

 

  • How much downtime do we risk if we need to scale up the Message Service with only one instance in non-HA?

The upscale activity always causes a downtime (usually very short - less than a minute or a few minutes) - also in HA mode.

  • Additional Consideration:
    • The Storage Class must be configured as Block Storage or iSCSI to ensure stable processing of the critical Message Service

HA setup for production 

Based on the sizing analysis conducted, I recommend deploying a High Availability (HA) setup with 3 worker nodes for both DEV/TEST and PROD.

Although the HA setup requires higher resources (20 CPUs and 64 GiB RAM) compared to the calculated non-HA requirements (13 CPUs and 50.5 GiB RAM), the delta of 7 CPUs is negligible compared to the outage risks of a non-redundant infrastructure. Crucially, it is not possible to switch from Non-HA to HA without completely redeploying the Edge Integration Cell.

Furthermore, a consistent HA setup across DEV/TEST and PROD eliminates transport errors and guarantees system consistency across all landscapes.

Recommended HA Configuration:

  • 3 Worker Nodes with a total of 20 CPUs and 64 GiB RAM
  • Message Service with 2 Replicas + Monitoring Pod for JMS High Availability
  • Block Storage or iSCSI for Persistent Volumes (204 GB)
  • PostgreSQL or HANA as an external database with HA replication
  • Starting directly with HA prevents future migrations and data loss

Hi there Jeet...thanks very much for the response

Could you just direct me to where deltas are supported by standard? 

We find that once the data is in datasphere by way of the replication flow that we don't see an option for the delta (by data flow or transformation flow. This seems to go backwards on functionality we had previously. 

It seems the only way we can delta through the system now is to

a) delete the data that is there in target - so basically the system just does a full load of 'delta' data through the system . But that means we only ever have the delta.

I have tried Replication flow to transparent table (is delta) - but only to that initial transparant

then after (and this is the issue - staging data through the system)

dataflow to from table 1 to table 2 - Not delta

Transformation flow from table 1 to table 2 - Not delta

Replication flow from table 1 to table 2 - Not supported

 

thanks - Rich

entry.title: Re: Display-Only Authorization for Manage Tax Rates & Sal...
entry.content:
Hi @Zong ,

It's possible, you can configure display-only access for the Manage Tax Rates and Manage Sales Prices apps in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition by adjusting the business roles and catalogs. SAP does not provide a dedicated "read-only" app variant, but you can restrict authorizations at the catalog level so users can only view condition records without being able to create, edit, or delete them.
Business Roles: Access is controlled through business roles that bundle business catalogs.
Business Catalogs: Each catalog defines what actions (create, edit, display) are possible in an app.
Restrictions: Within catalogs, you can apply restrictions to limit actions to "Display" only.

entry.title: EWM Outbound Delivery Goods Issue Dump MOVE_CAST_ERROR in /SCWM/PRDO
entry.content:
Problem
While posting Goods Issue for an outbound delivery order in SAP EWM, the system terminates with an ABAP dump.

Error details

  • Runtime error: MOVE_CAST_ERROR
  • Exception: CX_SY_MOVE_CAST_ERROR
  • Program: /SCWM/CL_IM_DLV_PPF_SCHED=====CP
  • Method: SCHED_TU_CREATION
  • Component: SCM-EWM-DLP

The dump occurs when saving the delivery or posting Goods Issue via /SCWM/PRDO.
The failure happens during standard scheduling logic for TU creation.

At first glance, this looks like a code defect.
The dump points to a failed cast between delivery header classes.
No relevant SAP Notes appear when searching by class or method.

Root cause
The issue is caused by incorrect configuration of the action profile assigned to the outbound delivery document type.

Solution

Check the outbound delivery customizing.

Path

SIMG> SCM Extended Warehouse Management > Extended Warehouse Management > Goods Issue Process > Outbound Delivery > Define Document Types for Outbound Delivery Process

SIMG > Navigation Path

Steps

  • Locate the entry for Document Category FDO
  • Select the outbound delivery document type
  • Verify the assigned action profile
  • Correct the action profile if it is inconsistent

Once the action profile is corrected, Goods Issue posting works without dump.

Practical note
In our case, the issue was initially analyzed as a technical defect due to the dump signature.
Only after reviewing delivery configuration did the root cause become clear.
This experience within the ALTZEN team reinforced how tightly EWM runtime logic depends on correct PPF configuration.

SAP Reference
SAP has documented this behavior in KBA 3685116.
note - 3685116

entry.title: Behind the Curtains - what's new about Maintenance Certificates
entry.content:
Blog posts often highlight changes that are severely impacting your business if you do not read the documentation or release notes thoroughly (and let's be honest - who has time for that?!). But not this time – relax, there’s no immediate call to action and no big changes impacting your daily business. This is all about a small improvement that highlights SAP’s ongoing push for automation and simplification of processes. And even more: It's one puzzle piece to reduce your dependency of SAP Solution Manager on your journey to SAP Cloud ALM. 

Maintenance Certificates are a crucial safety mechanism that ensures your system is part of a valid maintenance contract, allowing SAP to provide proper support. Until now, it was your responsibility to ensure that the certificate was properly renewed and distributed to the SAP system. Tools like SAP Solution Manager offered automation for this, but it was still a customer obligation to make sure the process was in place. 

Now, upfront distribution is not required anymore, and the eligibility check is fully automated. Here’s how it works: 

  1. One central SAP Host Agent in customer landscape is configured to communicate with SAP Support Backbone. 
  2. SAP Host Agents of other systems communicate via the central SAP Host Agent. 
  3. The SAP Support Backbone holds the information about the valid certificates which is automatically requested via the Host Agent mechanism if needed. 

And the best part? After an initial configuration of the federated SAP Host Agent Setup you do not need to worry about License Management anymore! This functionality is delivered via (minimum) SPAM version 91 that is all part of Software Logistics (SL) Toolset 1.0 SPS 45, and requires minimum SAP Host Agent version 67. You can find more information on the necessary configuration steps for SAP Host Agent here:  SAP Host Agent Federation | SAP Help Portal 

Of course, there’s a fallback solution: If the automated process is not set up, you can still manually request a valid maintenance certificate in the SAP Support Portal and install it manually in the system or distribute it via SAP Focused Run or via SAP Solution Manager (please keep in mind that mainstream maintenance for SAP Solution Manager 7.2 is only available until the end of 2027). 

For the Tech-Savvy: 

The entire flow is a collaboration between License Management (transaction SLICENSE), SPAM, and SAP Host Agent. It is used also by Software Update Manager (SUM). All the tools are combined in the SL Toolset. 

If you encounter any issues, please open an incident under component SV-SMG-LIC. Feel free to ask questions below this post and let us know what you think!

entry.title: Re: Customer Classification setup to be captured in a TR
entry.content:
Hi @MuraliRN ,

The reason TCode CL02 and CT04 don’t prompt for a TR. CL02 (Class maintenance) and CT04 (Characteristic maintenance) are considered master data maintenance transactions, not configuration.
Master data changes (like creating or editing classes/characteristics) are stored directly in tables and do not trigger transport requests automatically. That’s why you don’t see the TR popup when saving.

How to capture these changes in a Transport Request
Since you want to move this setup across systems (e.g., from Dev → QA → Prod), you need to use transport tools for master data. Use Transaction R3TR / Transport Organizer. Go to SE10/SE09 and create a transport request manually. Then include the relevant objects (characteristics and classes). Transaction SCM or SCC1 won’t help here because those are for client copy. Instead, you need Transaction CTMC (Transport Classes) → allows you to select classes and assign them to a TR. Transaction CTMS (Transport Characteristics) → same for characteristics.

The alternative way to do this is, Use Transaction SE03 → Object Directory → Transport Object Types.
Select object type KLAH (Class) or CABN (Characteristic). Assign them to a transport request.

Program-based method, SAP provides reports like RSTRANSP or R3TR object entries for characteristics/classes. You can run program RDDIMPDP or use R3TR CHAR CABN <char_name> to include them in TR.

entry.title: Re: Customer expected price condition type EDI1
entry.content:
Hi @KVKUMAR ,

That's correct, this is standard behavior. The condition type EDI1 (Customer Expected Price) is a statistical condition in SAP. It does not replace the actual pricing condition (like PPR0). The "Accept customer price" action in the Fiori app only acknowledges the discrepancy but does not overwrite the system-calculated price. If you want to use the customer’s expected price as the actual price, you must adjust the pricing manually or configure a custom routine to copy EDI1 into the main price condition.

The reason EDI1 behaves this way because, EDI1 is statistical: SAP defines EDI1 (expected gross price) and EDI2 (expected net price) as statistical conditions. They are used to capture what the customer sent in their EDI order, but they don’t determine the final billing price. The system compares EDI1 against your calculated price (e.g., PPR0). If there’s a difference, the document is flagged as incomplete so you can review it.

Fiori "Accept customer price": This button acknowledges the customer’s expected price in the workflow but does not automatically replace the system price. It’s designed to help avoid disputes, not to override pricing logic
You’re not missing a setting—EDI1 is not meant to overwrite actual pricing. If your business requires that behavior, you’ll need a custom enhancement or manual intervention. Would you like me to walk you through how to configure an alternative calculation routine so that EDI1 can replace PPR0 automatically, or would you prefer to explore tolerance-based acceptance where small differences are auto-approved? configure alternative calculation routine for EDI1, set tolerance checks for customer expected price

entry.title: Re: ARM Error - Refund control "Immediately" already used...
entry.content:
Hi @rajeshkumar0311 ,

This error occurs because the Refund Control “Immediately” option is already assigned and active in your SAP Advanced Returns Management (ARM) configuration. SAP does not allow the same refund control to be reused or unchecked once it has been deployed in production. To resolve it, you need to either create a new refund control variant for your approval process or adjust the existing configuration without attempting to uncheck the “Immediately” option

Refund Control Uniqueness, In ARM, refund controls (e.g., Immediately, By Credit Memo Request, No Refund) are unique identifiers. Once “Immediately” is used in production, it cannot be unchecked or reassigned. Approval Process Conflict, Your requirement to release a credit memo via approval conflicts with the “Immediately” refund control, which bypasses approval and issues refunds directly.

System Safeguard, prevents changes to refund controls already tied to live transactions to avoid inconsistencies in financial postings and return workflows

entry.title: Master Blog: SAP Edge Integration Cell – The Hybrid Integration Journey
entry.content:
Overview of SAP Edge Integration Cell Master Blog – The Hybrid Integration Journey

Migrating to the SAP Integration Suite doesn't mean moving all your data to the public cloud. For sensitive "Ground-to-Ground" scenarios, you need a solution that keeps traffic strictly within your private landscape. This is where the SAP Edge Integration Cell (EIC) comes into play.

 

 

This Master Blog serves as your central guide for the SAP Edge Integration Cell journey—covering everything from initial planning and architecture to ongoing operations. Whether you are transitioning from SAP PI/PO or starting fresh, this series will guide you through every step.

Below you will find the collection of deep-dive articles, which will be constantly updated as we progress through the journey.

 

SeriesTopicDescriptionLink
01Initial Sizing & HA/non-HA PlanningWe start by laying the foundation. This post uses real-world PI/PO performance data to calculate the necessary infrastructure for the EIC. It also clarifies the critical differences and requirements between High Availability (HA) and Non-HA setups.SAP Edge Integration Cell- Initial Sizing Approach and Planning for HA/Non-HA Setup 
02Coming soon...  

Stay Tuned

This series is designed to be a "living document." Make sure to bookmark this page or subscribe to the blog to get notified when the next parts of the series are published.

Do you have specific questions about the Edge Integration Cell that you would like to see covered in upcoming posts? Let me know in the comments!

entry.title: SAP on IBM i: SAP Support Required PTF Lists have been updated
entry.content:
On November 21st, 2025, IBM i 7.6 TR1 was released along with Db2 for i PTF Group SF99960 Level 2, as well as IBM i 7.5 TR 7 along with Db2 for i PTF Group SF99950 Level 11 and IBM i 7.4 Db2 for i PTF Group SF99704 Level 32. You can get a quick overview over the enhancements for IBM i 7.6 at https://www.ibm.com/support/pages/ibm-i-76-tr1-enhancements and for IBM i 7.5 at https://www.ibm.com/support/pages/ibm-i-75-tr7-enhancements. A general entry point for the various Technology Refreshes with their enhancements can be found at https://www.ibm.com/support/pages/node/1119129.

The SAP Support Required PTF Lists, formerly known as Information APARs, have been updated to include these new levels. Together with the Technology Refreshes and the Db2 for i PTF groups, the cumulative PTF packages and the High Impact/Pervasive PTF groups were updated. For IBM i 7.3, only the High Impact/Pervasive PTF groups was updated.

The PTF lists can be found at the following links:

IBM i 7.6: https://www.ibm.com/support/pages/sap-support-required-ptf-list-ibm-i-76
IBM i 7.5: https://www.ibm.com/support/pages/sap-support-required-ptf-list-ibm-i-75
IBM i 7.4: https://www.ibm.com/support/pages/sap-support-required-ptf-list-ibm-i-74
IBM i 7.3: https://www.ibm.com/support/pages/sap-support-required-ptf-list-ibm-i-73

If you want to download the PTF lists to your SAP systems with the help of a program, take a look at our sample program and blog entry from July 18th, 2022.

Note: If you are using IBM i 7.4 or 7.5, it is advised that you pay attention to the individual LIC PTFs listed in the PTF lists in order to avoid performance degradation under certain circumstances.

We recommend that you apply the current PTF levels for preventive maintenance whenever you are performing your next scheduled maintenance.

entry.title: A journey from Netweaver 7.50 to S/4HANA - Part 4: Custom Code Conversion Conundrums
entry.content:
After the preliminary steps for our custom code conversion described in part 1, part 2 and part 3 of this blog series, we finally started the actual coding activity over the summer.

To begin with, about 120 objects needed to be tackled which had been classified as high priority by the functional and business teams, many of which would most likely be needed for process testing in the first of eventual four sandbox systems. Once done with those, a big list with about 2,500 objects needed to be processed by our development team. For this blog post I picked three issues we encountered and briefly describe how we tackled them.

What to do with customer master creation or updates via XD01 and XD02?

We have several programs which create new customers or update existing customers via batch input (or call transaction) logic based on transaction XD01/02 and targeting the "old" tables KNA1, KNB1, KNVV, etc.  While the tables still exist in S/4HANA, the transactions are no longer functional because customers now have to be created and maintained as business partners via transaction BP and the business partner tables are in the "lead". The old tables are then filled from the BP, so are still available but only for read access.

Some of our logic creates customers in bulk based on file uploads and we needed an alternative route for that because many users are relying on that logic. Other programs call XD02 in order to update some fields in the customer master. Searching for alternatives, we happened upon class CL_MD_BP_MAINTAIN and method MAINTAIN, which - based on OSS Note 2484299 - BAPI list for BP - is the recommended "tool" in S/4HANA for these kind of tasks (the BAPIs (FMs) listed in the note are intended for an ECC-system).

At first glance, using this class and method looked straight-forward enough, given that it only requires one import parameter:

cl_md_bp_maintain=>maintain(
  EXPORTING
    i_data   = l_data
  IMPORTING
    e_return = l_return ).

The "fun" really started once we realised what this parameter "i_data" really is ... very deeply nested structure CVIS_EI_EXTERN! The "complex" in the description doesn't really do it justice - at the very least, I would have added an "extremely" before "complex"!

High level definition of deeply nested structure CVIS_EI_EXTERN

To get a better handle on what I was looking at, I extended all the structures and all of their sub-structures until reaching the lowest nesting level for each of them.  I then downloaded everything into a spreadsheet which ended up having 18(!) nested levels in columns A to R and over 32,000(!!!) rows. Here is a small snippet taken from the spreadsheet:

Green rows are for fields, blue lines indicate a (sub)structure and yellow rows tabletypes.

Based on a code example found in a helpful blog post here in SAP Community, we started to piece together the code needed to fill this gigantic structure in order to create a new customer in our system. By now, we do have some working code but are still working out some details for specific cases where only some fields need to be updated instead a new customer created.

Syntax error while testing logic for Australia but due to a vanished table related to Taiwan

As most of you will already know, SAP calls the OSS-notes related to a conversion to S/4HANA "Simplification Items" because SAP simplified the underlying database by eliminating tables and table fields and - to state the obvious - this makes the switch to S/4HANA anything but simple, at least if you have a large custom code base like we do! 

While our development team has been working through the custom code conversion, other teams are already testing processes in sandbox systems. These were created based on productive systems which - even though the code is sourced from the same development system - differ in the data they contain. One is for example a small system for only one company code, while another one is used in Asian-Pacific countries, so is much larger than the first sandbox to be converted and also covers many more test cases. Testing processes related to webshop orders for Australia came to a stop when the logic ran into a syntax error because a table and its structure needed for e-documents in Taiwan was found missing.

Dump due to a syntax error

The table KNA1_TW_EXT contains just a handful of fields but they are legal requirements in Taiwan for invoices. A simplification item exists for the table but it's only the rather generic one mentioning objects no longer available in S/4HANA and it doesn't go into anything specific: 2296016 - SAP S/4HANA custom code adaptation - removal of orphaned objects. So, we were wondering what happens to the data stored in the productive system in ECC during system conversion?

Digging around a bit more, I found OSS-Note 3166424 - eDocument Taiwan: Migrate Extension Fields for Electronic Documents for Taiwan directly related to table KNA1_TW_EXT. In it, the conversion steps are explained and - guess what? - they involve manually downloading the data from table KNA1_TW_EXT while still on ECC and then - again manually - running SAP-provided program EDOC_TW_CUST_MIGRATE to add the fields' content to their "new" location which is funnily enough table KNA1! Unfortunately, we didn't have the upload program in our system and the OSS-Note wasn't applicable to our version of the S/4HANA-system anyway. 

So, the next step was to create an SAP incident to ask about the note's applicability in our system and to get some confirmation that these manual steps are actually necessary. We got both quickly and could then run through these motions in the sandbox system. And these steps will need to be added to the big check list for needed manual activities when the actual productive system gets converted sometime next year. 

The need for and fun with Retrofit

Given the long-running nature of our custom code conversion and process testing in sandbox systems, we obviously couldn't impose a freeze on the productive landscape still on Netweaver 750 EHP8 (ECC). We therefore needed a means to keep our new S/4HANA landscape up to date with new developments and applied changes in the corresponding ECC-system. With help from SAP, a Retrofit system based on Solution Manager was established and can now be used to "merge" changes applied in the ECC-system with the code in S/4HANA.

Simplified system landscape

Once transports hit our ECC productive systems, they become relevant for Retrofit in S/4HANA. The transports are automatically checked and the ones without conflicts - new objects, changed objects for which no S/4HANA code conversion has happened and which don't have S/4HANA Readiness findings - are directly imported into the S/4HANA development system. Other transports are held back for manual inspections.

While the Retrofit framework handles report programs and includes just fine by displaying differences in the two code versions side by side, it has its limitations when it comes to Adobe forms and enhancements. For these objects the side by side comparison doesn't work and it would need to be done manually via version compare which can not just be tedious but also rather error prone. Because of that, we are now asking our colleagues who applied changes in these objects in ECC to re-apply the same changes - adapted to the S/4HANA needs - in the S/4HANA development system. 

Generally and speaking from a Retrofit perspective, any change not applied in the ECC system is a good change. Even with the tools available in Retrofit, the effort increases with frequent changes in ECC to objects already converted to S/4. And with each new change, the complexity and chances for errors increases.

This concludes part 4 of our journey from SAP Netweaver to S/4HANA - I'm sure that 2026 will throw some more curve balls our way!

Cartoon generated with Gemini

entry.title: Re: Close customer project from "Contract preparation" stage
entry.content: Hi Meenu, in S/4HANA Cloud the project lifecycle is quite structured, so even if a project is no longer needed, the system expects it to follow the standard status flow. That’s why it doesn’t allow a direct close from “Contract Preparation.” If there’s no billing involved, the usual workaround is to move it to “In Execution” with a minimal setup and then close it, or mark it as canceled depending on your configuration. It’s more about keeping process consistency than actual billing in this case.

entry.title: Looking Back to Move Forward: Field Service at a Turning Point
entry.content:
If 2025 taught us one thing, it’s this:
Field service is no longer just about fixing what’s broken. It’s about keeping the world running — intelligently, sustainably, and human-centric.

Over the past year, organizations across industries have rethought how they plan, dispatch, execute, and learn from service. Not because technology forced them to — but because customers, technicians, and the business demanded it.

At SAP Field Service Management, 2025 was a year of momentum

From Digitalization to Real Transformation

For years, digital transformation in field service meant replacing paper with mobile apps or spreadsheets with dashboards. In 2025, the conversation shifted.

Customers began asking different questions:

  • How do we reduce cost to serve without burning out our workforce?

  • How do we improve first-time fix rates when skills and parts are scarce?

  • How do we orchestrate employees, partners, assets, and data as one connected ecosystem?

The customer stories we shared this year — from EDF Power Solutions, ONTRAS, and Siemens Energy — show what happens when service and maintenance execution is no longer fragmented, but connected end-to-end.

Different industries. Different challenges.
One shared outcome: transforming how work gets done, connecting people, assets, and data to drive better results.

AI Becomes Practical — and Embedded

2025 was the year when AI in field service stopped being a standalone capability and became part of everyday work.

Instead of “AI for the sake of AI,” customers adopted AI where it truly matters:

  • Dispatchers receiving AI-powered insights and summaries that make understanding workloads and activity trends faster and easier

  • Planners benefiting from intelligent filters and recommendations that simplify planning across teams and regions

  • Technicians getting contextual insights before, during, and after a job

At the center of this experience is Joule, SAP’s AI copilot — bringing intelligence directly into the flow of work. Not replacing human judgment, but augmenting it, safely and transparently, with enterprise-grade trust.

Data as the Foundation for Intelligent Operations

None of this works without data — not just more data, but connected, meaningful data.

In 2025, we saw a clear shift toward using SAP Data Cloud to harmonize operational, and business data. This enables organizations to move from reacting to events to anticipating and preventing them.

For field service and maintenance alike, this means:

  • Better planning based on asset behavior and service history

  • Improved technician preparation and decision-making

  • Continuous learning loops between execution and strategy

From Assistance to AI Agents

Another important evolution in 2025 was the move toward AI agents.

AI agents don’t just answer questions — they help monitor situations, surface risks, and propose next best actions across planning, execution, and follow-up. Especially in complex environments, they reduce cognitive load and help teams focus on what matters most.

This is not about automation for automation’s sake.
It’s about supporting people in making better decisions, faster.

From Point Solutions to End-to-End Asset and Service Execution

One of the clearest signals from 2025 was this: customers are no longer looking for isolated tools.

They want end-to-end processes — spanning maintenance and service, planning and execution, assets and people — seamlessly connected across the business.

Within the SAP Business Suite, SAP Field Service Management plays a key role in bringing this together: connecting asset management, service execution, supply chain, finance, and customer experience on a shared data and AI foundation.

Our end-to-end product demo shows how SAP delivers a unified solution to keep operations running — across service and maintenance — intelligently and at scale.

👉Watch the SAP end-to-end service demo:

Built Together: A Heartfelt Thank You to Our Partners

One thing we want to say clearly as we look back at 2025:

SAP could not have done this alone.

More than 140 partners worldwide specialize in and support SAP Field Service Management — bringing deep industry expertise, regional presence, implementation know-how, and long-term commitment.

Whether helping customers transform service and maintenance operations, adapt solutions to specific business needs, or guide organizations through change — partners are an essential part of how value is created.

The strength of SAP Field Service Management lies not only in the software, but in the ecosystem behind it.

Looking Ahead: Continuing the Journey

As we look toward 2026, we know one thing for sure: the journey continues.

The next chapter is not only about customer service.
It’s about service and maintenance — together.

Strengthening SAP Field Service Management in the context of asset and maintenance processes will be a key focus going forward. 

In 2026, we will continue to build toward:

  • More intelligent execution across service and maintenance

  • Deeper integration across the SAP Business Suite

  • AI and data that support people, rather than overwhelm them

Because the goal hasn’t changed.

Thank You — to Our Customers and Partners

Finally, a sincere thank you.

To our customers, who challenge us with real-world problems and trust us to support some of the most critical operations in the world.
And to our partners, who bring expertise, creativity, and commitment to every transformation journey.

2025 reaffirmed what matters most: technology only creates impact when it serves people and purpose. Together with our customers and partners, we are building service and maintenance capabilities that are intelligent, sustainable, and human-centric. And as we move into 2026, we will continue to focus on what truly counts — keeping the world running.

Program CL_XCO_GEN_O_PUT_ABSTRACT=====CP
Application Component BC-SRV-APS-EXT-XCO
Date/Time 12/16/2025 14:12:52 (System)
User CB9980000126 (1765878167245-181841)
Client 100
Host appserver-6nl58

What happened?

The exception of class "CX_XCO_GEN_PUT_EXCEPTION" was triggered but not caught anywhere in the
call hierarchy.

Since exceptions represent error situations, and this error was not
adequately responded to, ABAP program "CL_XCO_GEN_O_PUT_ABSTRACT=====CP" had to be terminated.

Error analysis

An exception has occurred in class "CX_XCO_GEN_PUT_EXCEPTION". As this exception was not
caught, a runtime error occurred. The reason for the exception
occurring was:
PUT operation failed.

Information on where terminated

The termination occurred in ABAP program or include "CL_XCO_GEN_O_PUT_ABSTRACT=====CP", in "IF_XCO_GEN_O_PUT~EXECUTE". The
main program was "SAPMHTTP".

In the source code, the termination point is in line 9 of include "CL_XCO_GEN_O_PUT_ABSTRACT=====CM008".
include "CL_XCO_GEN_O_PUT_ABSTRACT=====CM008".

    DATA(lo_findings) = lo_ongoing_operation->get_findings( ).

entry.title: Re: Optimizing Your SAP S/4HANA Landscape with a Best Practice Role Concept
entry.content:
Hi Joe

it depends on the size.

Smaller companies might not need a tool after the first go live, as adding / removing company codes is not "daily business", and e.g. one or two sets of roles derivations might be created manually / supported with standard functions like PFCGMASSVAL / LSMW or similar. For sure it is also possible to request a service (e.g. as a minor change request) in case of a large number of derivations is required - in this case not the whole service needs to be reordered but just a small part of it.

Large size customers where the lifecycle of company codes is daily business might need a dedicated tool to support the automation of role development process. The Role Management features of SAP Access Control supports the definition of so called "Org Sets" and the automated derivation / updated. There is also a bunch of other tools on the market supporting similar features.

BR, Markus

entry.title: Re: S4HANA SPS Update SDMI (Silent Data Migration) CL_NGC...
entry.content:
Hello,

Had the same issue: resolved it following this note:
3597327 - The SDMI (Silent Data Migration) CL_SDM_QM_STXH finished in client XXX but XXX new entries are found that are still/again valid for migration
You need to execute a migration class again after it has been finished. 
1)Reset the status of the migration class in transaction SDM_MON -> button Current Client info -> Edit -> -select class->Restart finished Migration
2)Execute report R_SDM_ONLINE_EXEC with the following parameters:

Name of migration class : (Class in question)

Max. no. of parallel threads      =          4

All checkboxes must be unchecked!

Then initialise the phase again.
Hope this helps

Thanks
Neerja Sharma

entry.title: Upload failed "Permitted file size exceeded" despite file being < 5MB (HCMFAB_MYPERSONALDATA_SRV)
entry.content:
Hi Community,

I am currently trying to create an Action Project in SAP Build Process Automation (SBPA) by uploading an API specification from an SAP On-Premise system.

The Scenario:

  • Service: Standard SAP HCM Service HCMFAB_MYPERSONALDATA_SRV (Metadata).

  • File Format: .xml (renamed from .json to ensure correct parsing).

  • File Size: 3.1 MB (on disk).

  • SBPA Limit: The UI states the limit is 5 MB.

The Issue: When uploading the metadata.xml file, I receive the following error message:

"Invalid File. Artifact information could not be retrieved.. Permitted file size exceeded. The file must not be larger than 5 MB."

My Analysis: Technically, the file is well below the 5 MB limit. However, this specific OData service is very large in terms of schema definition because it contains EntitySets for almost every country version (e.g., PersonalData01, PersonalData02 ... up to PersonalData99).

It seems like the internal parser in SAP Build crashes or times out due to the sheer number of entities, even though the physical file size is within limits.

Question:

  1. Is there a hidden limit on the number of entities/complex types for the Action Editor?

  2. Is there a recommended way to "pre-filter" the metadata file (e.g. only keeping PersonalData01 for Germany) without manually hacking the XML structure and risking syntax errors?

Any help or workarounds are appreciated!

Best regards, Daniel Eckstein

entry.title: Re: Extra licence for Scope Item 1RK?
entry.content:
Dear @MelanieG,

Two important points for Public Cloud:

1.1RK is being replaced in release 2508, SAP states that scope item 7MI is the replacement for scope item 1RK

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/ee9ee0ca4c3942068ea584d2f929b5b1/ee6e1bd4c69f46ad8f653434326f2b8e.html?version=2508.00

So in CBC scoping you should plan to use/activate 7MI rather than 1RK

2.License / extra subscription for most customers, mass maintenance / mass load for BP is not a separately priced add-on it’s typically part of the Public Cloud capabilities

More details from SAP for Me:

 

SAP Note below:

https://me.sap.com/notes/3646136


The definitive way to confirm for your customer contract is to check whether the scope item is flagged as license-dependent / requires additional S/4HANA Cloud license in the Availability and dependencies of scope items list used with SAP Central Business Configuration (CBC)

I your case NOT extra license

SAP describes this exact check in Note below:

 https://me.sap.com/notes/0003539934

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Time Recording in SAP Project System with CATS (1) -Time Recording to WBS Elements
entry.content:
1.   Introduction

In most project-based organizations, accurate tracking of time spent on project work is essential. Many companies use Cross-Application Time Sheet (CATS) to enable employees to enter their working time on assigned tasks for detailed time recording. The integration between Project System (PS) and Cross-Application Time Sheet bridges the gap between project execution and actual time tracking, ensuring that human resource effort is reflected in project actuals and confirmations automatically.

Time recording allows project cost tracking and budget control, provides input for capacity planning and resource utilization analysis, and ensures that actual effort and progress are visible in the Project System.

Project System provides two structures: work breakdown structures (WBS) and networks. Depending on your project needs, the project structure can be designed using either WBS elements, networks, or a combination of both. Due to the fundamental difference between WBS elements and Network structures in SAP Project System, where WBS elements serve as planning and cost control objects, and Networks (with activities) serve as operational execution objects, the behavior of time recording and cost posting also varies accordingly.

In this blog series, we provide scenario-based demonstrations of end-to-end processes, including

  • Time Recording for WBS element,
  • Time Recording for Network Header,
  • Time Recording for Network Activity/Element

together with the “Project Builder” and “My Timesheet (S/4HANA / Version 4)” (F3074A), which is available as of SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS01.

Project Builder and My Timesheet Fiori Apps

This documentation includes the prerequisites for enabling the integration and a step-by-step guide for the first scenario - Time Recording to WBS Elements (the other two scenarios will be described in the upcoming blogs). Both planning and execution phases are addressed in each scenario. The goal of this documentation series is to provide users with an overview of the integration between PS and CATS, and to help them troubleshoot when setting up the integration in their own systems.

2.   Prerequisites

This section outlines the foundational configuration and master data required to enable time recording and cost posting to Project System objects. While some prerequisites apply to all scenarios, certain details may vary depending on processes.

2.1   Activity Type

Activity type is a unit of measurement for a particular activity, like Machine, Labor, or Maintenance. In the context of Project System (PS) with CATS integration, an activity type is a prerequisite in scenarios where internal labor needs to be planned using activity-based cost planning or where actual cost posting is required for WBS elements and network activities (with confirmation).

You can create an activity type using transaction code KL01 and maintain its price with respect to a cost center using KP26 for activity price calculation. Additionally, you can assign a list of activity types to a work center in the Costing tab under Activities Overview.

2.2   Work Center

A work center in SAP represents a physical or logical resource where project work is carried out. In the context of Project System (PS) with time recording, Work center is a prerequisite for activity-based internal labor cost planning, for person assignment in network activities, for automatic worklist generation in CATS, and for capacity planning in network activities.

You can create a new work center using transaction CR01 or make changes to an existing one using transaction CR02. For time recording to different object types in Project System (PS), different work center settings are required. 

For activity-based internal labor cost planning, the work center must allow usage (Usage setting) in network activities, and a cost center must be assigned. One or more activity types should exist with prices maintained in KP26 for the same cost center assigned in the work center. A standard value key is required to define measurable effort (e.g., labor time), and a corresponding formula must be assigned to convert effort into duration and cost.

For capacity planning and evaluation, the Capacities tab of the work center must include a capacity category (e.g., labor) and a defined available capacity (typically in hours per day), which is used for scheduling and overload checking. A formula must be assigned to calculate the available capacity. The standard value key is also required.

For person assignment in the network, optionally, you can link employees to a work center through HR assignment. HR resources can be assigned to a work center via HR assignment. In the Person Assignment tab in a network activity, when the checkbox Only from w/p is activated, only persons who are linked to the assigned work center (via HR master data) can be assigned to the network activity.

2.3   HR Mini Master

You can maintain a subset of core HR infotypes using SAP HR Mini Master by creating personnel using PA40 with the corresponding action type (Infotype 0000) or by using PA30 to maintain infotypes for existing personnel. These core infotypes enable an employee to interact with the system for time recording, person assignment, and other functionalities.

For time recording to (Project System) PS objects, you must set up the HR Mini Master with the following infotypes:

  • 0000 (Action Type),
  • 0001 (Organizational Assignment),
  • 0002 (Personal Data),
  • 0105 (Communication).

Optionally, you can define the default cost center and activity type for time entry in Infotype 0315 (Default Values Time Sheet). When performing capacity planning in network activities, it is recommended to set up the Infotype 0007 (Planned Working Time) to enable accurate capacity evaluation against working schedules.

2.4 CATS: Data Entry Profiles

The CATS Data Entry Profile (configured via transaction CAC1) defines the behavior and UI of the time sheet entry screen. In the My Timesheet Fiori app, employees can switch between available entry profiles using the Switch Profile button, allowing different configurations for different use cases.

Default Values

Default values reduce manual input by automatically populating fields such as:

  • Controlling area
  • Activity Type
  • Receiver Cost Center

These values can be derived from the HR Mini Master (Infotype 0315), the work center, or the profile itself. If no default exists and no user input is provided, cost transfer may fail due to missing costing information. 

Worklist Settings

Worklist generation is used to propose relevant project objects (e.g., network activities) to the user when recording time.

The following checkboxes influence this behavior:

  • With Worklist: enables the Worklist tab in the My Timesheet app or GUI, allowing users to select assigned tasks (such as network activities/activity elements with person assignment).
  • From Resource Planning: includes assignments from Workforce Planning (transaction CMP2). Ensures that employees see activities assigned via capacity planning.
  • From Project Assignment: includes network activities with direct person assignments made in the Person Assignment tab of the network activity/activity element.
  • Customer enhancement: standard worklist generation supports only network activities/activity elements with person assignments. To extend this (e.g., for WBS elements), implement BAdI CATS_WORKLIST_ADDIN. The BAdI allows you to define custom logic for generating worklist entries per user.

These options must align with how planning and person assignment are done in your project setup. For example, if your resource assignments are maintained only in PS (not Workforce Planning), the second option may be unnecessary.

Configuration in the example CATS entry profile

Integration with Project System (PS)

To ensure the integration with PS:

  • The profile must allow transfer to PS (e.g., via program CAT5 or RCATSTPS).
  • The activity type, receiver object (WBS/Network), and cost center must be valid and consistent with Project System settings.
  • The network or WBS element must be released (REL status) and allow actual postings.

Approval

If approval is required:

  • Enable the Approval Procedure in the profile.
  • Define who the approver is via workflow rules.
  • Time entries must be approved before they can be transferred to CO/PS.

Approval setting in the example CATS entry profile

2.5   Authorization and HR Integration

Authorization

Users must be assigned the appropriate authorization roles to access and operate the CATS (Cross-Application Time Sheet) and Project System (PS) integration features. This includes:

  • Authorization to use specific CATS data entry profiles.
  • Authorization to record, approve, and reverse time entries.
  • Authorization to execute time transfer programs (e.g., CAT5, CAT7).
  • Access to related master data (e.g., WBS elements, network activities).
  • Authorization to view and analyze cost and confirmation data in PS.

Ensure these roles are correctly assigned through your security/authorization team before starting the time recording or transfer processes.

Integration

ALE (Application Link Enabling) is only required if your HR system is separate from the controlling/PS system (distributed systems).

3.   Scenario A: Time Recording to WBS Element

In PS, you may want to record time directly to a WBS element when your project requires cost tracking at a high level, without the need for detailed operational execution via network activities. WBS elements do not support person assignment or capacity planning. Therefore, worklists are not generated for employees in their timesheets. Instead, employees must manually select the WBS element when recording their working time using CATS.

This demo walks through the complete process of recording time to WBS elements in SAP S/4HANA Project System (PS), including cost planning, time entry via My Timesheet Fiori app, cost transfer, and actual cost analysis.

3.1   Project and WBS Element Setup

We created a project (DL-BAD.015) in Project Builder with three WBS elements with high-level cost planning. In the WBS element, we can, e.g., plan high-level costs related to capacity using Easy Cost Planning (ECP) or manual entry. Cost planning for WBS elements in DL-BAD.015 was performed using transaction CJ40. The detailed planning process will not be covered in this session as it is not the focus of this discussion.

WBS elements are structured as follows:

DL-BAD.015.1 – Requirement Analysis

DL-BAD.015.2 – User Training & Rollout

DL-BAD.015.3 – Testing and Validation

When creating WBS elements, you need to pay attention to the following configurations:

Set the Planning Element indicator to allow cost planning.

Set the Account Assignment Element indicator to allow actual postings (e.g., time, material).

These are indicators that can be found in the Project Builder Basic Data tab for WBS elements.

Project DL-BAD.015 (Project Builder) PE: Planning Element Indicator; acct: Account Assignment Element Indicator

Cost planning for WBS element DL-BAD.015.1

To enable actual postings, the project must have system status REL (Released). Otherwise, time entries will be blocked.

Release the project

Example: Attempting to record time against a WBS element while the project is in status CRTD (Created) results in an error. 

Error when recording time to a non-released project

3.2  Create an Assignment in the My Timesheet App

When recording time to a WBS element in the app, you can either create a new time entry manually every time or create a reusable project assignment for the WBS element.

The latter option improves efficiency for recurring tasks. To create an assignment, go to the My Timesheet Fiori app, click on the Assignments button on the top right. The following fields are mandatory:

  1. Receiver WBS Element: must be a valid account assignment element.
  2. Activity Type: derived from HR Mini Master Infotype or defaults in CATS profile (see 2.3, 2.4); if not, the user must enter it manually. If it does not exist, no cost can be calculated from the activity type rate.Select the WBS element DL-BAD.015.1 as the Receiver WBS Element for assignment creation

In the example, it is derived from the default activity type from HR Mini Master Infotype 0315. Furthermore, the activity type must have rates maintained in KP26 (see 2.1).

3.3 Record Time to WBS element

From the Edit view of the My Timesheet app, open the value help dialog on a specific date and select the assignment just created. Enter the number of hours and check the entry. If the check is successful, click on Submit. If an approval workflow is active (defined in the CATS Data Entry Profile, see 2.4), the time must be approved before transfer.

My Timesheet app Edit view

Select assignment from value help dialog

After the check is successful, we can submit the time.

Time entry is auto approved

3.4 Transfer Time Records

Till this step, the cost has not yet been transferred to the controlling (CO). Use report RCATSTCO or transaction CAT7 to post time entries. A log is posted indicating that the transfer was successful.

In the example, transfer time entry to CO is performed only for relevant example employee

Transfer to Controlling successful

3.5 View Posted Costs

The screenshot shows that an actual cost has been posted to WBS element DL-BAD.015.1 (Requirement Analysis)

Planned and actual cost for WBS DL-BAD.015.1 is highlighted (CN41N)

3.6 Record Time with Manual Activity Type Entry

As mentioned earlier, the activity type is read from the HR Mini Master. If no default activity type entry exists, you can manually assign it. To do this, edit the time record entry, enter an activity type that is valid for the employee’s Cost Center (price must exist for the activity type with respect to this Cost Center, see 2.1).

Edit activity type manually

By following the same procedure as 3.2-3.3, two actual costs are posted to WBS. You can review costs, e.g., by using the Project System Infosystem or the Project Cost Fiori apps. In this example, we can view the cost using the following apps:

  • CN41N – Project Structure Overview with Planned/Actual comparison.
  • CJI3N – Display Actual Line Items for WBS.
  • KSB5 – Display Cost Center Line Items by Activity Type.
  • S_ALR_87013532 – plan/actual/variance overview in SAP Project System

Two costs posting for WBS element DL-BAD.015.1 (CJI3N)

Planned and total actual cost for WBS DL-BAD.015.1 is highlighted(S_ALR_87013532)

Actual cost document for activity type Consulting (KSB5)

Actual cost document for activity type Assembly (KSB5)

3.7 Reverse Time Postings

To reverse an incorrectly posted time entry, first withdraw the approval (if an approval workflow is active), then delete the entry in My Timesheet and rerun CAT7. The system will automatically create a negative posting to reverse the original cost.

Negative cost posted for WBS element DL-BAD.015.1

This scenario concludes with the WBS element receiving actual internal labor costs from time recordings. At this stage, the project team can continue monitoring actuals against planned values, perform any required adjustments, and, if applicable, proceed with period-end closing or settlement activities. This completes the time recording cycle for WBS elements and sets the stage for further financial control and reporting in Project System.

entry.title: Re: Create GOS attachment from xstring document
entry.content:
Hi Missschaaa,

Add the OBJECT_HEADER parameter in Function Module , it will work

* Add the OBJECT_HEADER parameter in Function Module , it will work


t_objhead = VALUE #(

  ( line = |&SO_FILENAME={ lv_file_name }| )

  ( line = |&SO_DESCRIPTION={ lv_obj_descr }| )

  ( line = |&SO_FORMAT=BIN| )       "Important

  ( line = |&SO_FILEEXT=png| ) "png

  ( line = |&SO_OBJLEN={ lv_doc_size }| )

).



CALL FUNCTION 'SO_DOCUMENT_INSERT_API1'

    EXPORTING

      folder_id                            =  ls_fol_id

      document_data              =   ls_doc_data

      document_type              =   'PNG'

*      document_type              =  'jpg'

    IMPORTING

      document_info              =  ls_doc_info

    TABLES

      contents_hex                 =  lt_solix

      OBJECT_HEADER              = lt_objhead

    EXCEPTIONS

      folder_not_exist           = 1

      document_type_not_exist    = 2

      operation_no_authorization = 3

      parameter_error            = 4

      x_error                    = 5

      enqueue_error              = 6

      OTHERS                     = 7.

  IF sy-subrc <> 0 OR ls_doc_info-doc_id IS INITIAL.

  MESSAGE 'Failed to insert attachment' TYPE 'E'.

  RETURN.

ENDIF.

entry.title: MRP-RUN : STR ( stock transfer requisition) cansidred as depend Requirement befor approval
entry.content:
Hi,

I am facing an issue.

In our current project, the MRP strategy is based on special procurement. MRP generates a Stock Transfer Request (STR).

Manufacturing plant (1003):
When MRP runs, it generates a planned order. After that, we manually convert the planned order into a Purchase Requisition (Stock Transfer Request to the distribution plant, i.e., the supplying plant) using MD15.
These STRs are subject to a release strategy.

Distribution plant (1008):
MRP generates a Purchase Requisition based on the depend requirement generated from the manufacturing plant (1003) as an STR (Stock Transfer Request).

Requirement:
The dependent requirement in the distribution plant should be considered only for the Stock Transfer Requisition has been approved.

Current situation:
The system considers the planned order generated in plant 1003 as a dependent requirement in the distribution plant.

same for the STR NOT APPROVED 

Question:
How can we configure or handle this scenario in the system to ensure that only approved STRs are considered as depend requirement in the MD 04 of the distribution plant

entry.title: Attributes Learning Report after Migrating to TIH
entry.content:
We have migrated to the Talent Intelligence Hub in our stage environment. I am looking for a report that would help me crosswalk the competency GUID to the new attribute id. We thought we might be able to create a custom report but there are no attribute reports available in learning. The competency id field on the HCM side does not return the competency GUID. We also do not yet have report stories.

We have duplicate competencies in the system and would like to inactivate those that are not tied to a learning item but have only found a manual process to identify which ones those are as it relates to the new attribute id.

Does anyone know of a way to do this?
